page.title: 10FARMING NEAR PRINCES RISBOR;
page.content: There is quite a variety of farming in this area, related to the geology. Where the chalk is capped by clay with flints there are damp pastures that support sheep and cattle. In the valleys there are deposits of alluvium and gravel which permit both cattle rearing and arable farming. Much of the arable farming consists of barly and wheat, but some oats is also grown. The sheep are usually fed on concentrated foods and silage. A typical mixed farm in the area consists of eighty Jersey with a hundred or so young stock, and six Aberdeen beef calves. On the arable side there are a hundred acres of wheat and about a hundred acres of barly, sometimes an acre or two of oats are grown. Five acres are given over to potatoes, twenty to silage and thirty to hay.
